content.heading: The Main Quest

content.heading: PHASE 1: Define the Context
content.subtitle: Ditch the Detailsâ€”Focus on Core Logic

strategy_steps.title: Simplify the Text
strategy_steps.description: Strip away jargon, names, and complex terminology
points: Idea A (Before blank): What's the core claim?
Idea B (After blank): What's the core claim?

strategy_steps.title: Identify the Logical Bridge
strategy_steps.description: What's the relationship between Idea A and Idea B?
points: Is it Addition? (adding a new point)
Is it Cause/Effect? (one leads to the other)
Is it Restatement? (saying the same thing differently)

example.text: Aristotle disagreed, positing that knowledge is best obtained through direct engagement with the material world; ______ sensory experience of the material is the ultimate source of knowledge.

breakdown.idea_a: Knowledge comes from direct engagement with material world
breakdown.idea_b: Sensory experience is the ultimate source of knowledge

strategy_steps.description: What simple word would work here?

strategy_steps.title: Identify the Category
strategy_steps.description: Lock in which of the 5 categories you need

categories.Restatement: In other words, That is, Namely, Specifically

content.heading: PHASE 3: Flaw-Finding & Validation
content.subtitle: The 100% Rule: Find Why 3 Are Wrong, Prove 1 Is Perfect

core_principle.title: Context Is King
core_principle.description: We must find the word that is 100% provableâ€”not just 'sounds good'

tactics.name: Tactic 1: Rhetorical Purpose Check
tactics.description: Does the word match the author's precise intent?
tactics.application: Test each choice against your target category from Phase 2
red_flags: Wrong purpose (e.g., concession when you need restatement)

tactics.name: Tactic 2: Copycat Elimination
tactics.description: If two choices are synonyms, they usually both cancel out
tactics.example: If 'furthermore' and 'moreover' are both options, look elsewhere

tactics.name: Tactic 3: Precision Tie-breaker
tactics.description: When multiple seem to work, choose the most specific match
tactics.example: If both work logically, which one matches the exact rhetorical move?

worked_example.question: Aristotle disagreed... ______ sensory experience is the ultimate source.

B.flaw: Wrong purposeâ€”signals reluctant agreement, not clarification

C.validation: âœ… Perfect matchâ€”signals clarification of the same idea

D.flaw: Wrong logicâ€”ideas are directly related, not parallel

strategy_card.title: The 3-Phase Master Strategy

steps: Simplify: What's Idea A? What's Idea B?
Lock in the category (Addition, Contrast, Cause/Effect, Restatement, Example)
Check Rhetorical Purpose: Does it match author's intent?
Precision Tie-breaker: Choose the most specific match

strategy_card.the_100_rule: The correct answer is 100% provable. The other 3 have specific flaws.

common_mistakes: Choosing transitions that 'feel' right instead of predicting the category first
Getting distracted by complex details instead of simplifying to core logic
Not finding the specific flaw in each wrong answer
Picking technically correct but not most precise answers
